unnormalised: Lights, Camera, FESTIVAL! Your Guide to the World of Film Festivals
normalised: Lights, Camera, FESTIVAL! Your Guide to the World of Film Festivals

unnormalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and cinephiles! Ever wondered where all the *really* cool movies come from, the ones that aren't your typical masala entertainers? Chances are, they've done the film festival circuit. Film festivals are like the pilgrimage sites for independent filmmakers and discerning audiences alike. They're more than just movie screenings; they're vibrant cultural hubs.
normalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and cinephiles! Ever wondered where all the really cool movies come from, the ones that aren't your typical masala entertainers? Chances are, they've done the film festival circuit. Film festivals are like the pilgrimage sites for independent filmmakers and discerning audiences alike. They're more than just movie screenings; they're vibrant cultural hubs.

unnormalised: Think of it as a giant party where everyone loves movies, from the director to the light boys. Imagine seeing a film that no one else has seen yet, maybe even one starring your favourite actor, say, Rajkumar Rao, in a completely unexpected role. That's the magic of film festivals!
normalised: Think of it as a giant party where everyone loves movies, from the director to the light boys. Imagine seeing a film that no one else has seen yet, maybe even one starring your favourite actor, say, Rajkumar Rao, in a completely unexpected role. That's the magic of film festivals!

unnormalised: India itself is a hotbed for film festivals. The International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa is a big one, held annually in November. You'll find films from all corners of the globe there. Then there are smaller, more niche festivals like the Jio MAMI Mumbai Film Festival, focusing on Indian and international cinema. They often showcase films that challenge norms, much like the films they show at FTII, Pune.

unnormalised: But why bother going? Well, first, you get to discover amazing films that you wouldn't find in your local multiplex. Second, you get to meet the people who made those films – directors, actors, writers – and ask them questions. It's a fantastic way to learn about the filmmaking process and get a glimpse behind the curtain. Plus, the after-parties are usually pretty legendary!

unnormalised: Let's say you're into documentaries. There are festivals dedicated to that! Or perhaps you love short films. There's probably a festival for that too. You might even find a film from some remote corner of Arunachal Pradesh, telling a story you'd never hear otherwise.

unnormalised: So, next time you're looking for something different to do, ditch the popcorn-fueled blockbuster and consider attending a film festival. You might just discover your new favourite film, or even your future career path! And who knows, maybe you'll even bump into Anurag Kashyap while grabbing a chai.
